messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: O-dachi Koshirae
messages.msgSnippet: Thank s Jim, swinging a 9 foot sword would have taken some effort I m sure, just reading your next mail, I think with the length of that tsuka, then yes you
messages.messageBody:
Thank's Jim, swinging a 9 foot sword would have taken some effort I'm sure, just reading your next mail, I think with the length of that tsuka, then yes you could use it like a naginata, interesting stuff indeed. I found this, it may have been seen before, I'm not sure, the Norimitsu Ã”dachi is very impressive at 3.7 metres, massive, this is an interesting site and answers many of my questions

http://japantrip.tripod.com/nodachi/nodachi.html

cheers

Rich

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: O-dachi Koshirae
messages.msgSnippet: Hi matt, thanks fo rthat, I was meaning as a general rule, these swords being 9 feet long are certainly not prectical for use ( the quick draw wouldn t be too
messages.messageBody:
Hi matt, thanks fo rthat, I was meaning as a general rule, these swords being 9 feet long are certainly not prectical for use ( the quick draw wouldn't be too quick :-) ) I could only imagine these being made for presentation and or a gift.

Rich
----- Original Message -----
From: Matthew E. Hoyle
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Friday, May 02, 2003 8:21 AM
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Re: O-dachi Koshirae


"Many important military figures of the Heian and Kamakura periods gave
swords and armor to the shrine that have been preserved to the present
day. Rather than commissioning pieces to be dedicated to the shrine,
most of what was given was the actual weapons used successfully in
battle. Instead of being freshly polished and remounted, the swords
were presented "as-is" and for the most part have been retained as they
were received. "

- Matt

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] O-dachi Photos
messages.msgSnippet: The Kashiwa o-tachi has a thin yamagane tsuba.  That s the only published one I can think of that doesn t have a nerikawa tsuba. Jim Just a couple koshirae
messages.messageBody:
The Kashiwa o-tachi has a thin yamagane tsuba. That's the only published one I can think of that doesn't have a nerikawa tsuba.

Jim
Just a couple koshirae that go with blades. One is certainly a thick
kawa-tsuba, and the other is difficult to determine, but it is thin.

G

messages.subject: Re: O-dachi Koshirae
messages.msgSnippet: Folk - Re o-dachi,I remember a piece in the National Geo about fifteen years ago about the amazing disappearing Pacific tuna, including the sushi favorite,
messages.messageBody:
Folk -

Re o-dachi,I remember a piece in the National Geo about fifteen years
ago about the amazing disappearing Pacific tuna, including the sushi
favorite, bluefin. A number of big bluefin were shown kayoed on a
Japanese distributor's floor with the bidding about to start, with
the note that they could go for up, to $5k a pop. A sidebar story
had to do with bluefin cutting katana, about five foot nagasa, made
in semi-traditional manner (seems they were quench hardened
or "tempered", though possibly not fold forged, and likely not of
tamahagane), the heat treatment which resulted in the "loss" of one
every now and then. So it seems that even now, o-dachi live. "The
right tool for the right job."

NC

messages.subject: Re: O-dachi Koshirae
messages.msgSnippet: Hi all, I have a pictures of a Samurai utilizing a O-dachi to cut the breast of a horse in battle. Could this be used to dismount the rider. Fact or fiction???
messages.messageBody:
Hi all,

I have a pictures of a Samurai utilizing a O-dachi to cut the breast
of a horse in battle. Could this be used to dismount the rider. Fact
or fiction???

Grazie,

Pat Simone

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: O-dachi Koshirae
messages.msgSnippet: Hi all, ... something rendered much later? The drawing came out of a 1930s publication that did not identify the source.  Judging from the drawing style, I
messages.messageBody:
Hi all,

At 09:25 PM 5/1/2003 -0400, Jim wrote:
>...Is the drawing contemporary with the period of the armor and sword, or
something rendered much later?

The drawing came out of a 1930s publication that did not identify the
source. Judging from the drawing style, I would date it much much later
than the period when O-dachi was in fashion, perhaps even as late as some
1930s artist.

Mike Y.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: O-dachi Koshirae
messages.msgSnippet: Mike and Rich, Thanks for the very cool posts.  I wonder if this one: http://www.komonjo.com/temp/09.jpg might be fitted with a big iron sukashi tsuba instead
messages.messageBody:
Mike and Rich,
Thanks for the very cool posts. I wonder if this one:

http://www.komonjo.com/temp/09.jpg

might be fitted with a big iron sukashi tsuba instead of the nerikawa tsuba usually found on surviving koshirae. Is the drawing contemporary with the period of the armor and sword, or something rendered much later?

Jim

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: O-dachi Koshirae
messages.msgSnippet: Matt & Richard, Some very long blades were made for devotional reasons, however others in Nanbokucho and early Muromachi were intended for use.  Obviously they
messages.messageBody:
Matt & Richard,

Some very long blades were made for devotional reasons, however others in Nanbokucho and early Muromachi were intended for use. Obviously they were not drawn from the saya like katana. I suspect that they may have been carried more for intimidation value than for effectiveness as a battlefield weapon, but I'll have to defer to Tom and the other swordsmen on that. I suppose that they are not so different from a long pole arm.

Jim


I think you would be correct. Weren't most really long swords made for
some festival ? I recall reading about that somewhere.

- Matt


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: O-dachi Koshirae
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, These were made for use.  What makes Oyamazumi so interesting is that the early swords and armor preserved there were practical items that were in use
messages.messageBody:
Rich,
These were made for use. What makes Oyamazumi so interesting is that the early swords and armor preserved there were practical items that were in use before being given to the shrine. Many of the blades are full of chips and pits and most of the koshirae are very simple and/or in degraded condition. These are pieces are rare remainders of what was for the most part used up and discarded long ago.

Jim


Jim et all, were these piece made for shrines or something simular ?

Rich

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

some festival ? I recall reading about that somewhere.

messages.subject: O-dachi Koshirae
messages.msgSnippet: I uploaded an image of two 9 foot long, Nanbokucho era o-tachi koshirae to the group web site.  Go to http://groups.yahoo.com/group/nihontostudy/ and click on
messages.messageBody:
I uploaded an image of two 9 foot long, Nanbokucho era o-tachi koshirae to the group web site. Go to

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/nihontostudy/

and click on the Photos link at the left and then click on the folder. Both are fitted with nerikawa tsuba. I can put up photos of similar period pieces if anyone wants to see more.

Jim
